metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Amrutanjan Ltd.

facts.text: One Nageswara Rao Panthulu set up a business of manufacturing a pain-balm marketed in the trade-name of Amrutanjan.
In September 1936 the respondent company was floated as a public limited company under the Indian Companies Act, 1913, to acquire and carry on the business of manufacture and sale of Amrutanjan.
Authorised capital of the company was 7,000 ordinary shares and 3,000 preference shares of Rs. 100 each; issued and paid-up capital was 2,500 ordinary and 3,000 preference shares.
Preference shareholders entitled to a fixed dividend of 7% on the face value of the shares, with right in the balance of the profits.
Respondent company took over the business conducted by Nageswara Rao Panthulu for Rs. 5,50,000 paid in the form of 2,500 ordinary and 3,000 preference fully paid-up shares.

Company managed by a firm which after death of Nageswara Rao Panthulu consisted of Ramayamma (widow), Kamakshamma (daughter), Ramchandra Rao (Ramayamma's brother) and Sambu Prasad (Kamakshamma's husband).
Between April 1, 1946 to March 31, 1949 Ramayamma held 2,185 ordinary shares and Kamakshamma held 250 ordinary shares.
Out of preference shares only 385 held by directors including Ramayamma and Kamakshamma.
Under Articles of Association, both preference and ordinary shareholders entitled to vote at company meetings, one vote per share.
For years ending March 31, 1947, 1948, 1949, company declared total dividend of Rs. 38,750 each year (7.5% on preference, 6% on ordinary), less than 60% of amount available under s.23A.
Income-tax Officer served notice after approval of Inspecting Assistant Commissioner, ordered on March 31, 1953 under s.23A that undistributed portion deemed distributed as dividend.
Order confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.
Several contentions raised before Revenue authorities and Tribunal challenging competence of ITO under s.23A including unconstitutionality, negatived by Tribunal and High Court.
Tribunal referred three questions to Madras High Court under s.66(1); third question: Whether provisions of s.23A correctly applied for the three years?
High Court held respondent company one in which public substantially interested, ITO no jurisdiction under s.23A, answered question negatively.
No investigation by Income-tax Department whether group controlling the company.
Total voting power 5,500 (one vote per share, ordinary and preference); 25% is 1,375.

legal_issues.text: Whether the provisions of s. 23-A were correctly applied for the three relevant years?
Whether the respondent company is one in which the public are substantially interested, so as to exclude application of s.23A?

petitioner_arguments.text: Explanation to s.23A(1) defines company in which public substantially interested; respondent not such a company due to controlling interest.
Distinction between controlling group and public not along directors vs members; directors not in controlling group count as public.

respondent_arguments.text: Company is one in which public substantially interested.

court_reasoning.text: S.23A enacted to prevent avoidance of super-tax by controlling shareholders not distributing dividends; does not apply to companies where public substantially interested.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object to foil accumulation of profits to avoid super-tax.

court_reasoning.text: Explanation raises presumption, not definition: if shares (not fixed dividend) carrying not less than 25% voting power held by public, presumed public substantially interested.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fixed dividend shares excluded from 25% computation.

court_reasoning.text: Total voting power includes all shares; 25% of 5500 is 1375, but must be ordinary shares held by public outside controlling group; here Ramayamma holds 87.4% ordinary, no 25% public ordinary shares shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Explanation has no operation as presumption not invoked.

court_reasoning.text: No investigation whether controlling group exists to bring within third proviso; question of fact not decided by Tribunal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot decide controlling interest without findings.

holdings.text: High Court interpretation of Explanation incorrect; no presumption arises under Explanation.
Revenue made no investigation on controlling interest; cannot decide if company one where public not substantially interested.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Core provision for deeming undistributed income as dividend; proviso excludes companies where public substantially interested; Explanation raises presumption if 25% voting power (excluding fixed dividend shares) held by public.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Company incorporated under this Act; Articles govern voting rights.

outcome.summary: Appeals dismissed as High Court order affirmed on different grounds: Explanation inapplicable, no Revenue finding on controlling interest; cannot decide issue.

key_quotes.text: The Explanation had no application, because no presumption on the facts found could arise thereunder.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Whether in fact there exists such a controlling interest in the hands of one shareholder or a group of shareholders as would render the company one in which the public are not substantially interested is a question which therefore cannot be decided by this Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why appeals dismissed despite HC error.
